But the authors of this book aim to explain all of this in lay terms, for readers who don't have much of a background in math or science, "using mathematics no more complicated than Pythagoras' theorem," as they say in the introduction. The authors do this without condescending, and without boring readers, like myself, who aren't put off by the math. I learned much of this material in the year of physics I took as an undergrad, but the details have long since faded from my memory. In college, we flew through relativity at the end of a semester of classical mechanics. I followed how we got from point A to point B, but mostly as the explicit steps and derivations in my notebook. What I particularly like about this book wasn't that it recapitulated the derivations I saw 25 years ago, but rather that it gave me a much better intuitive understanding of how Einstein went from the physics of the late 19th century to his theory of relativity.The authors derive E=mc^2 about two-thirds of the way into the book. The remainder of the book is devoted to the "why should we care?" part of the title. The bulk of this is a long foray into particle physics and the "Standard Model" of modern physics. While this material was also fascinating and well-explained, it also provided the one (minor) weak point in the book. For most of this (long) chapter, I was thinking, "This is all very interesting, but what does it have to do with Einstein's formula?" In the end, the authors tie it all up nicely, but I would have appreciated a bit more context earlier in this discussion.I enjoyed this book, and learned (or re-learned) a lot in reading it. But I'm not really the target audience, and I can't speak to how well this works for readers who are less comfortable with math and science.

This book gave me some insight into how the speed of light gets into Einstein's famous equation. Space and time are not two different things. They are not two different absolute things. Space (distance) and time are relative. They depend on the speed of the observer. And also the choice of which of two observers is in motion is arbitrary. Each can reasonably say they are not moving and the other is the one moving. What is absolute is spacetime. Spacetime has 4 dimensions, three in space and one in time. Distances between events in space time are absolute. To represent all 4 dimensions in the same units, time can be converted to distance by multiplying time by c, the speed of light. All observers can measure a distance between two events in spacetime and get the same result even though they would observe a different time by their clock and different distance in space. Everything travels in spacetime at the “speed of light” c. This is the cosmic speed limit. To preserve causality, event A that causes event B can not happen in spacetime at a time after event B, it has to happen before event B. In a 2 dimensional diagram of spacetime with a time dimension and 1 space dimension, lines 45 degrees from the origin represent the cosmic speed limit. Anything traveling faster than this could catch up and happen before its causal event, thus violating causality. We can travel along the time axis without moving in space, thus sitting still as time passes. But we can not move along the space axis without moving in time because that would imply infinite speed. When objects approach the speed of light, the cosmic speed limit, time slows down and distances get shorter. Since everything travels through space time at speed c, if we travel a great distance at a great speed we are using more of our available travel potential on space leaving less for the passage of time. The math of relativity requires that something with zero mass must travel at the cosmic speed limit, c. Light has zero mass so must travel at “the speed of light.”

I have very mixed feelings with regards to this book. On the one hand, it introduced me to lots of fascinating concepts I had only heard of but never truly understood, but on the other hand, I don't feel I understand them now either. The writing ranged from condescendingly simple to very confusing - confusing, for example, in that it transformed relatively simple mathematical proofs into jumbles of narration that were very difficult for me to follow, although I was well acquainted with the actual math. (Just write the vector in vector notation, please!) I don't feel like someone who had never encountered the math before would have understood it, and the way it was presented made it unnecessarily hard even for those who have some knowledge to grasp it. Mathematical notation exists for the sake of clarity and simplicity, after all!I also feel like the author would describe a simple, intuitive concept for (p)ages, but gloss over more boggling and counter-intuitive ideas, so I felt I had to go back and re-read certain passages several times. Although certain things were very well explained, like the mass-energy conversion that is at the heart of the most simple energy-releasing processes, i.e. burning. The motorcyclist analogy I did not understand, but the nice geometrical proof of why things cannot go above the speed of light was really good. The last few chapters were also fine (except the last, about general relativity - I felt like I wanted a much more in-depth explanation), but I just felt the quality of the explanations really fluctuated and the whole thing lacked a bit flow; there were some rather abrupt changes of topic and too many "we'll explain it later"s .For all that criticism, it was an overall enjoyable read, and it has spurred me into researching relativity and the like a bit more, and I certainly learned something new and exciting about the universe. So, a solid 3-star!

Physics seems a whole lot more interesting than when I was at school. Maybe it was disinterested teens learning from disheartened teaching, maybe I was just never that into it, maybe I was drawn to the arts and away from maths and logic. Whatever the reason, I'm glad physics has caught up with me, dragged me by the hand and clung onto me, shouting look, look, look! Because, and I genuinely mean this, it's interesting. Why does E=mc2? by Professors Brian Cox and Jeff Forshaw aims to make the previously inaccessible accessible. Using Pythagoras theorem and relatively little maths, the pair manage to explain why energy is equal to mass times the speed of light (a constant) squared. Not only do the authors explain Einstein's world changing theory, but they (hopefully) make you understand it too. Somehow, I feel ever so slightly more well informed about the world I live in from grasping how, where and why this equation has come to be. I didn't have a Eureka moment so much as a slow trickling thought of ...hang on, that makes sense! I get it! To a point, because let's face it, the full intricacies and nuances of Einstein's theories will never be properly understood in a 200 and something page popular science book - physicists spend their lives understanding it. But thank the universe this book was written because suddenly physics doesn't seem a dusty subject full of old men but the cutting edge frontier of human knowledge. This equation has allowed us to go to the moon, observe distant planets and galaxies and created countless modern conveniences that we take for granted. My recommendation? This should be compulsory reading for all. The world could do with more information and understanding based on the logic and reason of science, rather than deniers and fantasists.

If I were completely subjective, as I am coming from an engineering background, and I'm already familiar with everything mentioned in the book, I would rate it much lower. But the fact is, it has no difficult mathematics, and the tone of the book should be understandable to people coming from non-scientific backgrounds, and as such, it is an excellent starting point.A fun fact, the book was published in 2011, before the announcement by CERN in 2012 of the experimental discovery of the Higgs boson. Thus some of the parts of what you read in this book are confirmed, and you will also understand what the big deal was with said announcement.

Cox and Forshaw do an excellent job guiding the reader through the scientific journey that led to Einstein's famous equation. Those lacking a strong background in physics (such as myself) should be cautioned that many passages will require a second, third, or even fourth reading before the concepts start to sink in. That said, after finishing this book I am confident that I can explain the following concepts in simple, easy-to-understand language:(1) All motion is relative(2) Space and time cannot be considered separately (except for approximations)(3) Energy and mass are, in many cases, interchangeableThe authors' lucid explanations, illustrations, and real-world examples allow them to explore these ideas without needing the reader to be a mathematician or physicist.The only thing keeping me from giving this book a 5-star rating is the last 3 chapters. After establishing the rationale behind Einstein's equation in the first part of the book, the authors proceed to dive into increasingly esoteric explanations for the origin of mass itself. Here, Cox and Forshaw are unable to maintain the clarity they achieve in the first 5 chapters. Their explanations of the Higgs Mechanism and survey of the Standard Model of Particle Physics are nowhere near as accessible as their explanations of the concepts mentioned above. Despite the ramped up complexity near the end of the book, I would not hesitate to recommend this book to anyone interested in learning more about the relativity of time and the significance of Einstein's famous equation.

I apologize for not knowing more about the other author, so I'll just discuss Brian Cox. When I was reading this book one thing was incredibly obvious: Brian Cox LOVES his job. Like, a lot. It rubs off well on the book and gets you interested. Then, stuff will go on a bit too long and get you disinterested. Sometimes the math was a bit too much, and I've generally been extremely strong in mathematics. I wouldn't say it's incredibly difficult, but reading this on an ebook it was often difficult what each variable was referring to. But, even though it was tedious at times, it was definitely worth it. Few books will leave you feeling so smart. The feeling is a strange one. Everything you always assumed about the universe and the world around you is mostly a lie formed by our assumptions. I liked the book a lot, but some chapters were simply unnecessary. I still don't understand the need for the entire (long) chapter on the different subatomic particles and the Higgs particle. I found it interesting, but it had very little to do with the book. Cox probably should have spent more time on the last chapter, which really should be half of the book (the other half being E=mc2).Make sure you take notes, as you should with any good educational book. You will remember much less than you think and the notes will make an excellent reminder every once in a while. I would definitely recommend this book but go in recognizing you'll get a bit bored at times and the pages won't go by nearly as fast as reading a fiction novel.

Is this a 5 star book in every way under my criteria? Probably not. It's more of a 3 star book. If you want to understand Einstein's Special Theory of Relativity this is a relatively (hah!) accessible book and is a fairly entertaining read. I give it 5 stars because it's my go to book every few years when I read about some new physics discovery and want a pretty quick refresher on some of the theory behind it. If you are wanting to understand it for the first time, it's a great read. If you have more than a passing interest in physics, don't read about it regularly, but want to refresh your mind on E=mc^2 every few years, this is for you.Fun facts:c is a measure of velocity. It's the universal speed limit. It's not so much the speed of light, it's the speed light travels because photons have no mass and anything that has no mass but exists will travel at that speed BECAUSEWe're all travelling at the same speed through a curved space-time. We all have the same angular momentum. Some things use their velocity through time, and some through space.* - Reserved for nonfiction. Worth a read if you're interested in the subject. Check out from library.** - Good. May be inconsistent and flawed, but overall worth a read if you're in the mood for that genre. Check out from library.*** - Very good. Recommended as a book that is either wonderfully written, informative, challenging, beautiful... but not all of the above. Check out from library or buy on Kindle.**** - Great. Go out and read.***** - Classic. MUST READ and should be on your bookshelf

This review is of an audio edition, although I did get the paperback out of the library as well so I could re-look at some of the equations and diagrams if need be. I'm really pleased I did this, as it became apparent that in adapting the book for audio some stuff had to be omitted; most notably the 'master equation' in the chapter on the origin of mass. It seemed very odd the way they kept banging on about the master equation on the audiobook without ever giving even a hint of what it looked like. When I saw the equations - 4 lines of fractions, powers, upper and lower case letters and just about every Greek letter I've ever met - I understood why it was excluded, but I felt some better way of explaining its absence than just skipping over it would have been preferable. To be honest, I struggled with the particle physics section. I can say, however, that my understanding of space-time, and Einstein's famous theories has greatly improved. I know some reviewers felt patronised by the tone of the book at times, possibly they weren't really the target market. I chuckled a bit at being advised to skip over the maths if I found it difficult, but appreciate that maths is a big mental block for some. The analogies given to help us understand the concepts where clear, imaginative and at times highly amusing. Co-author Jeff Forshaw was a great narrator, and I loved the Mancunian accent.

It's appropriate that this is the last book I read during 2013: I came into the reading year with a flerph by way of Joseph Citro's Lake Monsters (flerph = lazy raspberry) and I've gone out with a fizzle.Now, to be fair, this fizzle is not because of Cox and Forshaw's book, which is interesting and very well read. The fizzle is because this book is so very over my head, and because I made the mistake of pausing for about a week when I was a couple of hours into it. That meant that all of the math formulas and physics the authors had laid the foundation for in the first few chapters were well and good out of my head. And then, once I picked it back up, I never really caught back up with the material.The history of physics and math did stick, as did some of the early principles, like the impossibility of absolute time and motion. And what did stick was, in all truthfulness, so super cool. But either Cox and Forshaw gave me more credit than I deserved by saying that readers needed only a rudimentary knowledge of math, or I did myself the worst disservice by listening to this instead of reading a hard copy. I'll try to re-read this, which will be easy since it's short, and since Forshaw, who narrates this book, sounds quite a bit like Neil Gaiman, and that is very nice to listen to.

A mostly friendly book for newcomers, with more math than the popsci fare I consumed recently. This book explains the math & geometry behind relativity. Cox holds your hand through the manageable special relativity and Pythagorean theorem, then to the increasingly complex topics: spacetime, energy and general relativity. The more complicated math (the ones I'd like to see) were omitted from the book. Derivations can pop into existence. It's annoying, but considering that Einstein years working out the math... Cox knew this type of great editing will get the laymen through the end of the book. The author advises you to skip the math if you don't care for it, though. General relativity is better appreciated with a holodeck; since the book doesn't come with it, a great imagination is necessary to visualize the objects/events in spacetime. Why Does E=mc²? swings from consumable popsci text to the not very friendly math. Videos are superior in teaching something in 3D, but this book entertains, and chances are you'll find a better (still shallow, but better) understanding of the subject matter. 3.5 stars

At first you wonder "am I really going to read this book?" and then it comes the book. I had a traveller staying with me for a couple of days in Thailand and there's one thing I like the most is open-minded people (from my point of view) to recommend me books! The reason I hesitated a little bit is that there was one thing I wasn't that good at the school was maths and physics but then the authors definitely put things together in a way you can actually grasp the beauty of it (everything you could possibly imagine comes down to numbers and equations)Still when I saw equations, numbers, signs I've never seen before my eyes were reading it like a foreign language (maybe the one I have no idea about) and I trying (unsuccessfully) to understand it. Ok! I might have no understood the equations but certainly the authors brought to light in a simple way stuff like mass of matter, speed of light, energy produced by the sun/body, and etc...wow what a delight to read and get informed about this. If you're the kind of person who question the existence of matter, space and all that form it this will blow your mind and it's ok if you decide to skip the more scientific explanations of things. At the end you'll have a great picture of all that exists.

We all know Brian Cox by now through his captivating TV shows, with his infectious enthusiasm and the ability to explain science in simple ways, like demonstrating Mars orbital path using just a stick and a few rocks! Writing here with Jeff Forshaw, they set out to explain Einstein's famous equation so we can all finally understand it. I was a student of biology and chemistry so I have a science background coming into this, but physics is a subject I could never quite grasp. Whilst I really enjoyed this book, I can't boast that I understood it all. The first half was clear enough even when introducing a lot of the maths to explain spacetime, I felt like I was getting it. But from there on it gets more difficult. I think part of the problem is that the equations they are explaining could've been laid out better, I kept getting frustrated at continually having to flick back to see what equalled what and found myself getting a bit lost. Overall, a lot of the concepts were fascinating but be prepared to put some work into this book and possibly having to read it more than once to fully absorb everything, which is what I will be doing!

After reading several books that centre around the complex, at at times, mind-boggling world of Quantum Mechanics I was looking forward to tackling this offering co-authored by the ever popular Prof. Brian Cox.From the start I realised this wasn't like any of the other books I'd read and Cox makes no apology for the fact that to get the the solution, the reader has to wade through some pretty heavy-duty maths. In previous books one has been asked to perform thought experiments in regards to concepts offered but here the proof is in black and white in for form of maths. Despite this, you are told that you don't have to completely understand the figures to appreciate the beauty of the science. As with any book on this subject and open mind and willingness to embrace some very strange concepts is required.All in all, I enjoyed this book. It was very hard-going at times and although I read it mainly at bed time, I wouldn't recommend it for that relaxing bed-time escape. It is however, a book that has expanded my knowledge and understanding of this subject and at the same time has given me an appetite for more of the same.

My previous experiences with physics were limited to watching How the Universe Works (which, by the way, is an excellent program that you should check out if you've got Netflix streaming), so I went into this book armed only with the knowledge that E equaled MC Hammer and STOP!Hammertime![Dance mode INITIATED.]Anyway, authors Cox and Forshaw did a good job of dumbing things down and using interesting examples that helped me understand a lot of the concepts they outlined. Granted, there were parts that I didn't make a total effort to comprehend (if they think I'm honestly going to try and puzzle out the details of the Standard Model, they're mad), but in those instances I was okay with just taking their word for it.Some chapters were better than others; my favorite sections were the ones discussing things like how stars work (which was already somewhat familiar to me, thanks to the aforementioned Netflix series).If you've got any interest at all in physics, even if you don't know the first thing about the subject, this is a great place to get started.[END DANCE MODE.]

This book is an excellent introduction to Einstein and his theories for the layman. The mathematical concepts demonstrated require only a basic level of algebra, and maybe a little understanding of basic geometry, but nothing you didn't already learn in high school. And at it's heart, that is the real purpose of the book: to demonstrate to you that science is not really hard; all you need is a little curiosity and some passion for exploring concepts.The book will walk you through the basic steps that Einstein did to discover the equation E=mc2. Along the way you will discover the beauty of the universe and towards the end of the book they will step into a bit of the theory behind quantum mechanics, but not too much of the math at that point as it is a bit more complex than the layman may be able to follow.I loved the final statement from Mr. Brian Cox, that the universe does not care about ego, and will knock down a theory as fast as it gets constructed if it does not pass experimental evidence. This is how science works and progresses forward with better models than those that came before. This is how we grow and discover the universe at large.

In the novel Why Does E=mc2?(And Why Should We Care?), author Brian Cox thoroughly educates the reader on Einstein's famous theory of relativity, as the title implies. Cox introduces the theory to readers in simpler terms for the more ordinary person to understand. However, make no mistake, this book is not necessarily for everybody.In Why Does E=mc2(And Why Should We Care?), Cox explains Einstein's theory of relativity in a much simpler, yet still very complicated, way. Cox, with the help of Jeff Forshaw, explain the theory through the use of many confusing metaphors and comparisons to other theories. Through the use of these comparisons and contrasts, Cox shows us that some of these other theories cannot coexist with the theory of relativity, and some cooperate with it. Absolute time, space, and speed are just a few examples.I would recommend Why Does E=mc2(And Why Should We Care?) to most readers interested in science and physics. However, I do not recommend it to most readers that do not have extensive prior knowledge on the subject of physics. This is because many of the comparisons, explanations, and metaphors throughout the book are very confusing otherwise.

This review is specific to the audio editionWhilst far from being an expert physicist I have read a fair bit about relativity and quantum mechanics etc so I was coming to this book looking to get a clearer understanding of the subject matter it deals with. The only problem is that I don't think I'm any clearer now than when I started.I have no doubt that this is in large part due to the fact I was listening to it as an audiobook rather than reading it so don't want to put the book down too much. The book started off okay but quite quickly descended into multiple equations that I just found impossible to follow in my head which meant that large swathes of the book became impenetrable - and since each section relied on the previous it meant that everything went pear-shaped for me quite early on.The book is a good attempt to explain how Einstein reached his famous equation but in the end, at least as an audiobook, the ideas just required too much abstract and mathematical thought in order to properly ensure understanding.

Although I have always had a love of science at school and college I concentrated on chemistry, biology and geology. Physics was literally a closed book to me until fairly recently after rediscovering Carl Sagan's excellent series ""Cosmos"" and the book that accompanied it. The real problem for me with physics has always been the maths and formulae that make it hard to follow unless you have a teacher willing to slow down and lead you through the numbers very slowly. Step forward professors Brian Cox and Jeff Forshaw with this great book. In taking things right from first principles they keep things so simple that I finally understand why the speed of light comes into the theory of relativity. Relativity is not really a difficult theory to understand if it is explained properly by somebody that is not only knowledgeable of the subject but able to elucidate the facts in a way that a layperson can actually grasp without being swamped in scientific jargon. I cannot recommend this book enough for anybody wanting to understand how the universe actually works.

A good and thought-provoking book, and it certainly gave me some things to ponder. I am still mulling over the not entirely convincing explanation of the definition of distance in Minkowski spacetime and on the rather sleight-of-hand way that the famous equation emerges from conservation of momentum. I felt that deriving it this way was a bit of a con for a book whose title suggests the reader will acquire a better understanding of why it's true, not just how to prove it.I wasn't so sure about the long section concerning the master equation of the Standard Model. I'm not sure if something was lost in the editing (a few mistakes in the book made me think it had been rushed out) but I couldn't follow large parts of this section as the authors refer to things in the equation that aren't visible to anyone who doesn't know what the components mean. Still, it's interesting to see it, More to the point, it's interesting to know that such a thing exists and I guess I could read more on it elsewhere if sufficiently motivated.

I decided to give this book a try because I've seen Brian Cox's show, Wonders of the Universe, before and really enjoyed it. I thought it would be interesting to read a book expounding the relevancy of Einstein's equations in our world. However, science is definitely not my best or favorite subject, and I was a bit worried it might not keep my attention. I was pleasantly surprised. The authors seemed to direct the book at newcomers to physics, and their explanations were clear and easy to understand. I did hear other reviews mentioning that some might find the math too difficult, and others found it embarrassingly easy. I could see how this might irk people while reading the book; at times, the authors took the time to explain basic concepts such as the pythagorean theorem. I could see the purpose behind this- some readers are bound to have a more tenuous grasp on mathematics than others- but apart from the sometimes unnecessarily extended use of rhetoric, I found the book interesting and well-written.

As a layman who is interested in Physics and finds some books too technical and many others lack of precision and depth, I found this book brilliant and very helpful. It is an easy-to-follow popular science book, yet more profound than that. Most of all, it isn't a book that just throws out "facts", results and theories towards you. It gives the readers an opportunity to look into minds of the great, to think like a physicist and to understand how theories of Relativity and some other scientific ideas came into being. Finally, aided by this book, I came to understand Einstein's theories of Special Relativity in detail. It really has given me more insights into this subject than any other book I've read on the same topic. The only thing that left me somehow unsatisfied, is its brevity on theories of General Relativity, of which, the book only explains its concept. Although the mathematics should be difficult, I'd really like to learn more, by following a similar way that this wondeful book has guided us through previously.

Every time I read a physics book, I have to read it twice: once to read the words, and a second time to actually understand what I just read. As the authors of this book claim, I like to think it's because my brain can't visualize 4-dimensional spacetime. It's more likely, however, that I just don't get it.After several books on quantum theory, is tumbled on this in my library and realized I had never really asked myself the titular question. I've seen this formula in so many places that I just take it for granted, but I always do better when I understand the "why" of things, so I picked this up. I feel like it did help me to better understand some of what I've already read. I especially liked the path to viewing gravity as the curvature of spacetime.My quibble (because I always have one) is that I don't like being told it's okay to skip the maths if you don't enjoy that kind of thing. If you're trying to put the effort into learning about this kind of thing, put in your full effort and suck it up.

An introductory chapter shows that the idea of absolute time is untenable. A look at Special Relativity provides an easily understood derivation of the factor for time dilation. The idea of spacetime is then introduced. The chapter E=mc2 explores the equivalence of mass and energy."And Why Should We care" extends these ideas to the stars, looking at the mechanics of stellar evolution."The Origin of Mass" shows how relativity leads to a better understanding of particle physics, then examines the Standard Model and the relationship of the various elementary particles.A concluding chapter discusses curved spacetime and gravity, leading to General Relativity. Tests confirming the theory are shown to be in agreement with amazing accuracy. The GPS system includes correction for the clocks running faster in the satellites than the time on the earth's surface.Well written and perhaps on of the more accessible books on not only relativity, but it's implications in related sciences.

Nice read. I did not know that its not exactly "energy" that is equal to mass times the speed of light squared. However, Brian Cox tends to be very scatter brained while discussing the issues of relativity and space-time curvature. He will sometimes wander from topic to topic while discussing something in-depth and it took a bit for me to keep track of where he was. I would have also liked to have seen more math. Cox spends several paragraphs each chapter apologizing to the layman about the two to three equations he presents in the succeeding sentences and then presents an equivalent to the Pythagorean theorem. I get it Brian, you are excited to share physics with the lay man, but you don't need to assume that no one has ever had calculus or, indeed, even algebra. Give us some credit and explain things with equations. If you want to pander, give the equation and explain in detail what it means so we can chew over it.

So, why does E=mc^2? To be honest, even after reading the book I couldn't tell you clearly without second guessing myself quite a lot. However, I still absolutely loved this book and would recommend it to anyone and everyone.The fact of the matter is (hehe, matter...physics...get it? oh nevermind), while Brian has done an excellent job of trying to take the reader from point 'a' all the way through to point 'y=x^3' for those of us normal folk who live in the universe where space and time are absolute and a quark is something a duck does, the concepts were still not always totally clear and required several re-read through's before I could begin to consider of the ideas as part of reality rather than just another Iain M. Banks book (i.e. science fiction).Granted, it could all have just been me, but this IS my review so I get to say whatever I feel right? So, that said, go buy the book; it really is an excellent read. I know I personally...have already begun to read it again. ;)

Many moons ago when I was younger my dad gave me a copy of 'A Brief History of Time' I remember it took me absolutely ages to get through, and I'll admit, not everything made sense to me or sunk in but I finished it. Why Does E=mc2? is a great book. Both Cox and Forshaw have a brilliant way of simplifying what could potentially be a headache for the reader, or anyone who doesn't hold mathematics as a strong point. I was able to explain otherwise complex theories in a simplistic way to friends, which made me sound far more intelligent than I am, but also shows just how great this book is at describing Einsteins theory of relativity and physics. If you're not interested in Physics or have a hard time following mathematics then I would avoid this however, if like me you're fascinated by Physics, then challenge yourself and give this a read. Your mind will blown at numerous times in the book!

Despite physics not being one of my best subjects at school I have always had a fascination for it and so was looking forward to reading this book. I did physics a-level but went no further so my knowledge is not brilliant but even so I found the first chapter a bit condescending. It's so hard to write science books for a lay person so I don't really hold that against it. Things went downhill from there though. I made the mistake of trying to read the book at work where I found that there were just too many distractions and consequently I got lost pretty quickly and just couldn't retain my interest in it. I much prefer Ben Miller's physics book for what it's worth. It won't stop me from persevering with physics though; it's like a relationship in which one person is clingingly possessive of the object of their affections while the other brusquely tries to brush them off. Oh physics, why don't you love me?!

first let me say that I am not incredibly knowledgeable in the field of physics. I know only what my high school class taught me, and even then I don't remember all that much. this is not my typical genre of book, but I decided to try to venture out of my comfort zone a bit.I enjoyed the overall theme of this book, and how they tried to bring this whole concept down for the layman such as myself. I had never really considered the famous equation or that there was so much theory behind it. the authors did a really good job explaining everything.however, there were several points later in the book where they really got into the weeds and I found myself either re-reading passages two and three times, or just skipping sections entirely. that is really what kept me from giving it 4 or 5 stars.all in all, I really did learn from this book.

The start and end of this book are interesting and inspiring; the middle gets rather bogged down in too many words about spacetime vectors.I was also frustrated by the reference to sweeping up the ashes of a coal fire and finding that they weigh less than the coals - any chemist for the last couple of centuries would tell you that of course they do: most of the mass after combustion is carbon dioxide and other gases, not in the ashes. This obscures the tiny change in mass as a result of the change in energy associated with the chemical reactions, but that isn't made even vaguely clear.The enthusiasm of the authors for the beauty of the laws of nature and their power to predict and their benefits to us is clear and in places infectious, but the balance between comprehensibility and comprehensiveness is a difficult one not always achieved to my liking.

An extremely good layman's explanation of Einstein's theory of special relativity. It talks quite a bit about the standard model of particle physics and general relativity too. Unlike most books written for the general public, this one does not shy away from mathematics completely, and this is greatly to its credit. I did not follow the math in all of its details, but it is not necessary to do so to appreciate that these astoundingly accurate theories, which between them cover all of the known forces in the universe, are based on relatively simple math. The hard part is not the math, but the ability, which takes some practice, of letting go of our poor intuition about how stuff actually works.(Well, okay, the math for general relativity is apparently not simple at all, and it is appropriately not covered in the book.)

Since I can't rate this book six stars, I may have to adjust all of my other book ratings downward.I bought this as an audiobook for my daily commute. It's narrated by one of the authors, Jeff Forshaw, and the experience of listening to him was transformative. I will read this again in paper or ebook format, but his humor and emphasis (and accent) will stick with me.The authors succeed entirely in explaining E=MC^2 and why it matters... but they also explain why it matters that we ask these questions, and they left me with a new vision of reality that is achingly beautiful.Einstein's formulation of relativity theory was a crowning achievement of human imagination & willpower... but Cox & Forshaw's clear and clever (and remarkably short) explanation is a crowning achievement of literature and teaching.

A relatively easy to understand explanation of Einstein's famous formula and how it came about. I liked that Dr. Cox does not try to deify the man but rather focuses on his achievement and stresses the fact that scientific progress comes not through individual genius but though dedication, determination, collaboration and ingenuity. I came away with a much simpler and deeper understanding of the famous formula because of Dr. Cox's clear explanation of space-time and the importance of the cosmic speed limit 'c'.In the second last chapter the book veers off to explore the standard model of modern physics. This very brief introduction to such a complicated idea was a bit confusing to me but seemed to be mostly contextual, to place e=mc^2 as a pivotal step to the creation of that model and our modern attempts to find the elusive theory of everything.

Off this review: Why Does E=MC2? (And Why Should We Care?)By Brian Cox and Jeff Forshaw (Da Capo Press)To move beyond a cursory understanding of Einstein’s iconic equation, put yourself in the adept hands of physicists and science educators Brian Cox and Jeff Forshaw. Using clear language and a few clearly explained equations, they demystify physics’ most counterintuitive claims, connecting the dots between space-time, electromagnetic fields, invariance, and Galileo’s earlier theory of relativity. Cox and Forshaw place these ideas in context, ultimately demonstrating how the Large Hadron Collider, where Cox works, is an essential tool in a new level of understanding the laws of our universe.

I didn't expect much from this book at first and presumed it would be quite basic and over-simplified. While I did feel that in places some of the explanations went on a bit too long and the analogies were quite long-winded, I think the scope of this book and the wealth of information it gave was great - covering a lot of different areas from Physics related to relativity. Explaining relativity in terms most people can understand is no easy feat, but Why Does E=mc2 manages to do it reasonably well. There are parts of the book that seem a bit confused and in a few places a jump is made with no clear explanation of how we got there, but overall it gives a friendly approach to what is generally viewed as a complex and unreachable theory to the everyday individual.

This book tackled the job of explaining the relationship between space and time in a very readable, accessible way. The language is very ordinary, and complicated maths (in fact, almost any maths) is avoided....though mathematical explanations are available in appendices for those who want them.The balancing act between simplicity and condescension is a tricky one, and I did feel sometimes that the authors tipped over into condescension a little, but that's probably better than making things over-complicated and losing readers.On the whole, I found this book very interesting, and I even learnt a couple of feacts about relativity that I hadn't known before. If you're interested in physics/science, but don't have a strong mathematical background, I'd really recommend this book.

Brian Cox has written an outstanding explanation of the most famous equation ever derived. He introduces you to Special Relativity, teasing out its basic concepts, its nonlinear geometry, and its implications for the measurement of time, distance, mass, and energy. Any non-physicist interested in special relativity should read this book (yes, physicists, you can read it too). The level of mathematics is pretty primitive--simple algebra and Euclidean geometry--but the gist is explained well even without resorting to one's high school math. Of course, by now there are zillions of people who understand special relativity, and I'm glad to count myself among them. But as for General Relativity...?

Very interesting read. I admit I got lost during the whole derivation of Minkowski spacetime, but my concerns were actually mostly cleared up in the appendix. One of the sections that interested me most though was the section on the origins of mass, where the roles of the Higgs boson and other elementary particles were described. It's amazing how Einstein's theories could not only be so accurate (as shown by experiments), but also influence other fields, like particle physics and quantum mechanics. This universe is a mysterious place...I'd recommend this book to anyone who's interested in relativity, but that also has a head for maths, else you'll just have to take their word for it that certain equations are true.

If you're looking for a really simple, basic introduction to relativity, I'm not sure that this book is it. That's not to say it's badly written, or overly complicated, but it goes into enough detail that it's inevitably a bit hard going in places, especially for those for whom maths and science are pretty distant memories in their eduction.However, Brian Cox's infectious enthusiasm in the subject shines through on every page, and this makes even the more maths-heavy parts a lot easier to get through. And, to be fair, I'm not really sure what a simple introduction to relativity theory would look like anyway...

This book really opened my eyes to the issues modern physics deal with and I found it to be just at the right level of difficulty. As someone who liked physics in high school, but since then never dealt with it again, It was never too hard to follow but at the same time not too slow and patronizing. Makes you really think being a physicist is the most exciting job in the world. I listened to this as an audiobook and was surprised how well it works without being able to see formulas and diagrams. Part of the reason is probably that the authors try to avoid as they say any maths more complicated than Pythagoras and that diagrams wouldn't help much anyway visualizing multidimensional concepts.

An outstanding book and must read.They managed to explain such complex concepts as the distortion of space and time with just the Pythagorean theorem (you know, the length of the hypotenuse of a triangle). And then reaches the famous equation by adding momentum into the discussion. The concepts may be mind bending, but the maths is very basic and explanations clear and concise.The enthusiasm of the authors is infectious, and I came out of this book desperate to know more about relativity, particle physics and science as a whole.If you ever wanted to honestly say "I understand Einstein's Theory of Special Relativity, it's not so difficult", this is a must read.

This book isn't concise in any way. Cox Rambles on, goes off on pointless tangents and generally makes something really simple into something really complicated. Seeing as the whole book is just about deriving E=mc^2 and that takes the average physicist about 8 minutes to do you would think it would be simple. You would expect that for a wider readership Cox would expand, slow down and generally make easier the intermediate stages of the derivation. However, Cox doesn't make it easier. He maintains the high level, charges off down unfamiliar roads and makes the physics I know and love seem almost alien. I don't think I will be reading any more by this author.

Excellent and intuitive explanation of relativity. The first several chapters provide an amazingly clear explanation of how to derive special relativity from a small set of intuitive premises (using very few equations, which you can skip). I highly recommend it to anyone interested in understanding Einstein's theory. My only objection would be that his caveat about Einstein's brilliance in the final pages does not emphasize the extent to which Einstein's ideas were in the air of the time among Poincare, Lorenz, Hilbert and others at the time. I'm not convinced physics would be materially different today if not for Einstein, and I don't think Cox makes that clear.

Interesting reading and it made me aware of many aspects of relativity and physics. Topics of particular interest were the relationship of space and time into "Spacetime", how "c" is the universal cosmic speed limit and that the speed of limit just happens to be the same as c - because light is 100% energy and 0% mass (photons).I don't think I absorbed all of the information in the book as the subject is quite heavy going. Now I am listening to an audio book version where I have listened to about 60% of the book.I am sure Why is E = mc2 is worthy of re-reading, maybe after reading another book or two on the subject.

After read Orzel 's book, I tackled with this one. Orzel himself said on his book that this is a good introduction to Einstein's theories without any mathematical knowledge. Actually I failed to finish reading this book before. The reason is, probably my lack of basic knowledge on relativity. But I had just read Orzel's relativity book so this time I could read through. Cox and Forshow are always good guides for someone like me to apparently very complex theories. For someone like me who have non physics background, I would recommend to read together with Orzel's book. I thought it's interesting that Orzel has a dog and Cox and Forshow choose cat on their cover.

Completely amazing in elucidating a point of physics that is at once dauntingly difficult and also horribly misunderstood and misused by a great many spiritualists. Cox, with his British wit and charm and frequent reminders of chalk-covered professors, brings without much math this most elegant and incredible of equations to life beginning with the simplest of notions and proceeding to rock the phenomenological world off its hinges. None of this is to say the book is simple, there are concepts here not for the faint of intellectual heart, but as a conceptualization, Cox brings both special and general relativity to a plane that is accessible and mind-expanding.

There is a lot of good insight in here, and the concepts are explained carefully and clearly. The reason I had to give this 3 instead of 4 stars though is because I was offended by the constant need to apologize about the smallest amount of math. I don't know if I should blame the authors for this per se, but I only found it distracting and sad that the simplest algebra had to be explicated. Nevertheless if you can skim over the 'I'm sorry but math is important and here's why and if you don't like it it's okay you can skip over the next part' parts, it's worth the read to get insight into special relativity.

Einstein's theories are controversial, as many people today forget that they are theories and take them as facts, although there is no rational proof for them. This book tries to explain the space-time theory. It explains the basic assumptions, provides a few calculations as evidence, then takes a leap into assuming that this is all proven. It does not address any counter theories or the apparent intuitiveness of the theory, or even the geometry used to demonstrate it. That said, its a good book for getting into the mind of the modern day physicists, who blindly follow other's beliefs just as much as many religious people today do. Science: the new Western religion.

Good explanation of special relativity, with enough mathematics that you don't have to believe the words of the authors, yet easy to understand. Followed by 2 chapters about other theory's like standard model and general relativity. Over all, I think it was a very good book in popular science genre, a bit nearer to the academic science than the rest of similar books. Which I think is because special relativity is a very simple theory. I might read it again, specially the chapters about Minkowski spacetime.Any one who like to have a good understanding of special relativity, should read this book.

This is a very well-written, clear book that explains exactly how Einstein's famous equation was discovered. It is a bit dated because of the recent discovery of the Higgs particle but that's to be expected in this day and age of fast-moving science. You don't need any math background to read the book although the authors do have to use some basic algebra in their explanations. All in all this is one of the best books I've read on the why behind this equation. I picked it up because I've been asking the question that is the title of the book for a long time.If you like science - and you're a bit rusty on your math - this is a must read.

An fascinating book infused with passion and excitement, exactly what the world needs to encourage the next generation to be inspired to follow a career in the sciences. However, perhaps not for the typical younger reader. A lot of patience is required to read this book, if you anything like the average intelligent guy that I am with a laymen enthusiasm for these things. Re-reading was something I had to do for a lot of the very abstract ideas proposed in this book. Though, thankfully, I did grasps everything in the end, and once I did sink into a tub of comprehension, it was astounding what you realised you'd learnt.

Well generally I am happy I read this book. I never really understood the famous equation at school or any other quantum related science, which is a shame because I am very much interested.Do I now fully understand it after the book? The answer is honestly no. There was lots of mathematics in the book, which lost me most of the way. But I definitely got a better idea now, and I loved some of the anecdotes and stories in the book, and it had a few great comparisons which made it easier for me to understand. I will not become a quantum physicist now, but I have much better idea what it is about.

I have a slightly better grasp of relativity, and if I were to read the book again I think I would get even more. However, there seemed to be a lot of basic stuff.My main problem is that it doesn't answer the question in the subtitle. I was hoping for more everyday application stuff. One of the more interesting parts was about the global positioning satellites and it didn't come until the end.Part of my problem is that I would read before I went to bed and there were a lot of easy places to stop reading so I would fall asleep and then have to re-read the stuff from the night before.

It was a very interesting exercise to compare this with A Briefer History of Time, which I read concurrently with this. Like Hawking, Cox and Forshaw are extremely adept at putting across complicated ideas to a lay audience, although they do not shy away from using maths as much as Hawking (A Briefer History is, after all, A Brief History of Time with less maths in it). They are also just as engaging and witty. I often found that an idea I had not grasped in one book was explained in a way I could understand better in the other book. Both highly recommended.

Many books on modern physics try to popularise what can be a pretty thorny subject, but this one goes about it in a different way. It clearly explains some of the groundbreaking achievements of Einstein and others by deriving some astounding theories from first principles. Many aspects are successfully covered by this approach though later segments relating to the so called Standard Model are less coherent. All in all this is book makes accessible some of the most fundamental elements of physics and provides enough substance for the layman and science graduate alike.

It took me a while to get my hands on this book, and yet the wait was worth it. For those who have always wondered since school days, about the most famous equation of the last century and its relevance, this book clears the air. The authors have explained special and general relativity in a way that non-phycists/mathematicians like me can understand (though with a few re-reads of certain sections).I can finally say that if someone asked me to explain special and general relativity, I could manage my way to attempt it now. Thanks to this wonderfully simple book.

I am no mathematician but it seems one should care about an equation that explains energy, mass and light, so I braced myself for a difficult read – but found instead an entertaining journey through examples of “the unreasonable effectiveness of mathematics on the physical sciences.”Hats off to two authors one wishes had been your university tutors. Anyone who can explain infinity divided by zero - and make it chatty - deserves a good rating. The lack of the extra star is a reflection on my ability to concentrate - not theirs to explain!

I like the aim of this book, there's some good analytical humour too, but it strays so far off-topic it's difficult to keep track. I think its clear the authors struggled with balancing giving enough background to an idea and getting across the actual main thrust of the topic. It may be that this is a bit of an unfair appraisal, especially since I didn't even finish the book. However, I got through a really good chunk of it and was not a lot clearer on why E is the same as mc2. It can't be that hard can it??

A very enjoyable read. Though it does a good job early on of explaining relativity, spacetime and everything leading up to and including the infamous equation in the book's title, I feel it suffers from the same problem as A Brief History Of Time, that is, it gets difficult and loses the focus on explaining to the layman like myself. I still very much enjoyed the book though and will definitely read it again as it's given me a wonderful insight into subjects I've been interested in for a long time.

Starting with an explanation of the theory of relativity, the authors meticulously build the case for why energy must be related to mass, with the speed of light somehow mysteriously involved in the proportion. The origin of the concept of mass is investigated during a visit to the Large Hadron Collider, where the "God" particle was recently discovered. After discussions of energy and mass, the writers explain why the speed of light is involved in the famous equation.Serves as a nice introduction to basic modern physics.

Why Does E=mc²? (And Why Should We Care?) by Brian Cox is easily the best book I've ever read about special and general relativity targeted at the general reader. Cox takes the reader deeply into the theory. He painlessly introduces the reader to the basics of the mathematics needed to understand some of the more beautiful aspects of both theories and he does so more skillfully than any other writer on the subject - including Einstein himself. This is a must read for anyone who wants to be more scientifically literate.

A great little conceptual book on one section of modern physics. Doesn't get too involved and for anyone whose been interested in the field for a while will probably find it lacking. However its not marketed for us so I'm not reviewing it that way. For a pop science book it avoids math but still has more in it that Hawking's a brief history of time. Somehow surprising as publishers try to avoid math like the plague. While it can get a little nerd crushy about CERN and particle accelerators its a good book.

Written with the radical assumption that the greatest physical theories can be understood by the layman, the book covers special and general relativity, and quickly breezes through some of the interesting recent developments in quantum mechanics. It concludes with a refreshing rejection of the "cult of personality" surrounding Einstein and other prominent scientists. Einstein did not have "supernatural intelligence"; his genius lay in taking relativity and electromagnetic theory seriously.

Okay. I am sort of confused about it because I may give it an unfair rating. but I have to review it since it's part of my reading routine. Dear author Brian Cox, how do you expect someone who doesnt basically know pythagoras theorem to understand the fabric of spacetime or the Minkowski's space ?! What I learnt from reading non-technical physics books is that Understanding the book depend mostly on your previous knowledge of the subject regardless of the author way in presenting his goods. Nonetheless, The author can make the book interesting، engaging and enjoyable.

it looks considerably dumbed down. explaining things like "squared" which can be annoying. but it is relatively clear. about time dilation....why something moving away would appear to have it's time slowed is clear. but shouldn't the phenomenon be symmetric, A sees B slowed and B sees A slowed. and when B returns To A, isn't the effect reversed? why doesn't it cancel out? no explanation..ok they did eventually address that point saying something to the effect "that's beyond this book" :(it slowly made a shift from too simple to a little opaque

I really enjoyed the second half of this book and felt that it definitely improved my overall understanding of particle physics. I would've rated this much higher if it wasn't for the derivation of E=mc^2 at the beginning. I was disappointed that the authors described the mathematics as no harder than the simple Pythagorus equation when I struggled to understand it as a Mathematics undergraduate. After researching online I was able to follow their explanations but from the book alone I found it quite complicated.

If, like me, you never really "got" physics in school, but find yourself watching documentaries by Prof. Brian Cox and others regardless, then this is the book for you. I would also recommend it to teenagers as a good introduction to physics before they get bogged down in all those theories and equations in school.There are times that my brain was still playing catch up with what was said, but most of the time that was because I was too busy thinking "Wow!" or "Whaaaaat?! That's amazing!". I will definitely read this again in the future.

I enthusiastically began this book. I wanted to challenge myself, and finally see if this book could help me understand E=mc2, which my father tried to teach all us kids in his delightful way. Regardless of his best efforts I flunked physics. Brian Cox's friendly, easy going language and his explanations were fairly easy at first. I read many passages over numerous times, and felt I was making progress. But I hit a wall about half way through. I think I need to actually talk to, ask questions, work through the equations with. But, it was fun to try.

Really enjoyed reading about the science underpinning one of the most famous equations. The tone is conversational without condescention, and the theories and equations are explained in a way that's clear even to a complete non-scientist. It took me awhile to complete the book, because I had to take it slow to feel like I understood the concepts presented, but it was worth the effort. I would absolutely read another science book by Brian Cox.

Quite a demanding read at times. Some sections went over my head, but it was definitely worth persevering with it. It gave me a much better understanding of the theory of relativity and it how relates to spacetime and nuclear physics.I would probably need to read the book several times to do the book justice and to probably grasp the physics. I found the book to be more readable than Manjit Kumar's book on particle physics, which I also read recently.

I learned a lot about how the world works in reality from this book. At times it was difficult to follow, but I did come away amazed by how little I understood before about relativity, spacetime, gravity, and the nature of mass. The author does a good job explaining very complicated subjects in layman's terms, but this is far from a book for dummies. Highly recommended to those who are interested in how the universe fundamentally works.

For such a brief book, it sure took a while to get through. It turn out even condensed Einstein requires the rereading of sentences, like, five times. And the chapters on particle physics were impenetrable (clearly the authors' specialty).In the end, I have a much better understanding of relativity than I did going in. And apparently relativity brings with it a number of other super interesting facts about the physical world. I'm just glad I ended up choosing history as my major.

This is the 2nd time I have read this book. I thought about giving it 5 stars, seriously. But it is a book only some would enjoy. It just so happensthat this is a question I have asked many times and even though I have read and watched many people explaning the subject it has never been clear. That said this book comes as close as any to clearing up my understanding of the subject. Well done. And the topic is mind altering.

This is an excellent non mathematical (other than the Pythagoras' theorem) introduction to Special and General Relativity for the non-scientist. I wish I had had this book way way back when I was first trying to understand Relativity. The book does have one major flaw however. In chapter 7, "The Origin of Mass" the authors toss Feynman diagrams around with such abandon that more shadow that light is created. I suggest simply skipping chapter 7.

I'm starting to think that trying to learn anything other than bits of trivia from non-fiction is just a waste of time. If I want to learn anything permanently I'll buy a textbook. With books, unless I re-read stuff, it's just in one ear, maybe entertains me, then goes out the other.Parts of this are interesting but overall it feels like the sort of concept which I should be able to find summarised on a webpage rather than read a book about.

While this book is "accessible" I must admit that there were parts with which I struggled. I don't have a science background, but I do have a strong interest in the subject, so in this respect I may have been part of the target audience of this book. But I found this very enjoyable and I have a much better understanding of the theory of relativity. It truly is a beautiful and complex (beyond our limited adjectives) universe. Highly recommended.

This book was amazing. It really takes you step-by-step in explaining how Einstein derived this most famous equation from existing work. I couldn't teach it, but I certainly feel like I got a decent grasp of relativity and how it came to be discovered. I'm not sure you could really explain it any better or simpler. That said, I'd like to read it again just to cement it in. Highly recommended for folks interested in the subject.

I did not enjoy this book at all. If you are explaining e=mc2, you assume people have some knowledge of basic math and basic physics. It started to get tedious for me when they started to explain the concept of 'squared' eg 7squared equals 49; when they started to wasted paragraphs on how/why you can skip the mathematics and still follow the book, etc.And yet the concept is not an easy one to simplify I don't think - so sorry - not to be recommended ....

Woooo... this took me forever to finish because as simply as the concepts are explained, they're still pretty mind-bending. I think it's safe to say I haven't missed my calling as a physicist.This is a superbly fascinating, well-written book, and as soon as I've conquered my guilt at skimming sections that were too complicated for first-thing-in-the-morning bus rides, I'm sure it's a book I'll dip into again.

I purchased this book primarily on the strength of Prof Cox's TV series. But I found this book a little disappointing. It rambled to and fro, and was a bit hard to follow, in the "unpredictable" sense of the word.There were some real nuggets: why does C have the particular value it has? What is the speed in 4-dimensional space of various bodies? How does the high velocity of particles in accelerators affect their decay?

An awesome introduction to particle physics! Anyone looking to delve into the ideas that underpin our universe without being overwhelmed by potentially intimidating mathematics should definitely read this book. It wrangles the obscure and counterintuitive ideas around particle physics into and entertaining tangible format using simple algebra and geometry. A must read for the curious and intellectually limited nerd alike.

Having studied Advanced Higher Physics at school I knew a little about the topics in this book, but I would recommend this to anyone who hasn't had any previous knowledge of physics. I found this book very enjoyable as it explained complex theories without going overboard on maths and figures. Great read and well written however the only criticism I could have is the explanation of Minkowski Spacetime could have been clearer.

A very uneven book. Chatty in style, it covers some very basic things in more detail than necessary, and speeds over many new concepts rather too quickly. I had hoped for more content and less fluff. and more examples in the hard stuff. It contains a fair amount of (often difficult) background that goes beyond the formula itself. I suppose the book lends itself to multiple readings. You can skip over the fluff the second time through.

This is a perfect book for those who want an answer to the title question. Here the very articulate and celebrity physicist explains all the important concepts Einstein's equation taught us. From the speed of light to the idea of spacetime to the origins of matter, this book will make you feel thoroughly educated after reading. And there is no complicated maths or equations to stop you in your tracks.

Professor Brian Cox and Professor Jeff Bradshaw managed to turn what seems to be difficult and too complex for laymen to understand at all into something rather easy to follow though one still may not be able to understand everything completely. But the logics is very clearly and leads one to follow the thread to ponder over physics. A very very good read! I myself am a fan of Professor Brian Cox. He is simply articulate, and smart and intrigues one' s curiosity about science.

this would have earned four stars if it was as accessible as the authors seem to think it is. at times, they painstakingly explain concepts that the general reader probably already has an idea about, other times their explanations fall very short and their analogies make no sense whatsoever. my final impression is that, if someone were to ask me why does E=MC squared I would have to answer the same way I would have before reading the book: I don't know.

DNF. This book is so dry. It takes such a long time to get to the point that by the time it has I'd entirely forgotten where it started. I'm really enjoying reading about physics and astronomy at the moment but I did not get on with this book. I kind of felt like the introduction was telling me to be awed by the universe rather than actually telling me things that were awesome. Probably going to take this to a second hand shop and let someone else have a go.

An interesting presentation of Einstein's famous theory. Some of the examples they give are quite helpful in thinking through some of the theory's more interesting points. (E.g., a box of mousetraps that are ready to snap weighs more than the same box after they have sprung.) However, the second-to-last chapter was brutal (about why things have mass). The last chapter that gets into general relativity (i.e., gravity) was great.

Cox and Forhsaw, starting with a few basic principles such as the equivalence of distances in spacetime (a concept they also explain very well) derive E=mc2. They do a great job not only exploring the concepts of relativity and of particle physics (they cover the standard model and the Higgs particle) but also give real insight into how scientists look at the world, allowing the reader to experience the process.

The casual title belies the complexity of this book. It's one of few "popular" physics books that doesn't dumb it down all. I'm still trying to figure out spacetime, and frankly the relativity of time, although I understand it sort of viscerally. It makes me wish I had had better and more inventive science teachers.

Good book. I could hear the voice of Brian Cox in my mind while reading the book.While I can't say I fully understand why E=mc2 after having read this book, I have come to think differently about spacetime and about the nature of matter.It would be good if a TV series was created based on the book as a companion piece. Perhaps a visual explanation would enhance understanding the book.

"I can think of no one, Stephen Hawking included, who more perfectly combines authority, knowledge, passion, clarity and powers of elucidation than Brian Cox. If you really want to know how Big Science works and why it matters to each of us in the smallest way then be entertained by this dazzlingly enthusiastic man. Can someone this charming really be a professor?" Stephen Fry"

I really enjoyed reading this. It is an entertaining discussion of physics in simple mathematical terms. I think that this book should be read by all at one point when learning because "Why does E=MC^2?" is a question that we should all ask and understand at one point. And not take the equation for granted

Reading this book took me back to my carefree childhood as an inquisitive high school student interested to become an astrophysicist. Although, the details of Einstein's famous equation are obscure and complicated for the average person, the authors do an excellent job of taking out that complexity to a large extent. I recommend this book to everybody who cultivates a scientific bent of mind.

Brain scrambling stuff - but the ambitious professors claim to be able to explain the basics of Einstein's theory of relativity using maths no more complicated than Pythagoras' theorem.Hmmm.As it happens they started to lose me in the middle of chapter 7, but I think I got the gist of it, which is good. Right?

This book is very accessible for those without a base in mathematics or particle physics. The authors explain the nature of spacetime, special and general theories of relativity, the principle behind E=mc(2) and the structure of atoms in such a way that everybody with an interest in these subjects can understand with ease. I wholly recommend it.

This seems somewhat like a "physics for dummies" book, but was still over my head in some areas. I am a big fan of Dr. Brian Cox and his passion for physics always makes him very engaging. There were definitely some portions of this book where I could hear his voice in my head. It gave me a better understanding of why this seemingly simple equation is so profound.

Very concise and easy to understand read describing some of the greatest fundamentals of physics: special relativity, the Standard Model of particle physics, and finally special relativity. The result is a very fast read that keeps your interest up, and at the same time helps you to understand some of the deep mysteries of the universe.

There's nothing easy about the topic of this book. It's difficult material to understand even when the author is trying his best to make it easier.I didn't like his attempts at humour about math and how everyone hates it and how he kept putting it down. Not everyone hates it. I would have liked to see the equations but that's for a textbook not a pop book on physics.

With little more than Pythagoras and some basic algebra, Cox and Forshaw explain how Einstein derived E=mc^2, in the process clarifying what it means and why it's important. And it's full of Ionian Enchantments, that wonderful feeling when you suddenly figure out how everything in the world fits together with everything else in a simple elegant way you had never seen before.

Informative, but a bit condescending in places. I understand the subject matter is hard, but personally I feel the parts which cross over with Hawkings books are much better explained there. Had I not read Brief History of Time already, I'd have probably rated this higher in all honesty. Other than that, it was just a bit too prosaic for my liking as a scientific text.

Loved it! The book is beautifully written, filled with case studies and practical examples.The authors successfully build up the explanation of complex concepts from very simple descriptions. More science books should be written with this senesce of humor and clarity. I wish I had read it in highschool.

A well done explanation of the gravity of Einstein's discovery. Pretty accessible and a very logical build up. I was especially glad that I finally understood what the CERN was doing when it was looking for the Higgs Boston constant. Definitely an amazing understanding of what mass is. I will have to re-read this book as I did start to gloss over some of the definitions in the standard model.

Well I sort of know the answer, and I do know it slightly better than I did when I started this book. But lets just say I didn't get through it at the speed of light, and everything being relative it turned out to be a long slow journey during which I aged a lot more than my friends who were not reading it.

Not a bad book in regards to Quantum Physics and theory's of relativity. The passages are a little 'all over the place' and this book defiantly keeps the author and reader at a distance when you read. Highly opinionated and defiantly a hard book to set your teeth into. A fairly good insight but not the best written book.

Fascinating books which breaks down the most famous equation into layman's terms. It's just a shame that at college I did not have lecturers like Forshaw and Cox who can make science interesting and be able to grab the imagination. I found this a great follow up to Stephen Hawkings A Brief History of Time. Fascinating book well written and entertaining!

This book was incredibly thought provoking. I listened to it as an audio book, which presented some challenges. The authors go over some diagrams and formulas throughout the text and these were particularly hard to follow for a novice like myself. If you are a novice, like me, I recommend the paperback version of this text. Otherwise, I thought it was quite enjoyable.

This wasn't the easiest book on Physics I have read, yet it wasn't the hardest either. There is information and enjoyment in here for a broad range of interests and abilities. I got a bit tangled with the math and concepts towards the end but enjoyed the bits I understood and have a much better concept of space/time now

One of the most concise and accessible books on modern physics there is. Brian Cox is a well known name in physics and is currently on several shows about modern physics and the universe. He has a great voice that keeps your attention even as the book through the more confusing parts of the book.

A very interesting book. I listened to the audio version which made it a bit hard to follow the mathematical equations. I got lost several time during the book but persisted and got a lot of interesting information out of it. I think high school maths and physics knowledge are a distinct advantage before you reading this book.

I dare not say I understand special relativity and general relativity, but I can confidently say that I have a much better concept of modern physics.Also, Einstein's thought experiment probably really is the most powerful thing in this world.Now I'm more interested in the CERN result that the LHC will be revealing.

The book is written in very simple way. Anyone not having mathematical understanding, or not heard of timespace or Standard Model whatsoever can understand it. The book clearly derives the famous equation by simple mathematics. But sometimes it takes too many pages for easy maths or some physical concept. That is why I am going for 4 stars. I recommend this book to anyone interested in Physics

I listened to the audiobook, as read by Jeff Forshaw, one of the authors. It was a bit difficult to follow along at times but mostly because I didn't have the math in front of me. It was good enough to just listen along and take the narrator at his word.This book helped me finally understand how time and space dilations work.

This book tries to communicate Einstein's concepts in an approachable undaunting way, though from a lay perspective rushes some explanations somewhat. Also the claim that you can ignore the maths and just focus on the punch line is not borne out, as you need to grapple with it anyway. It's funky, and I liked it.

This author does a great job of explaining relativity, basic particle physics and more. Rivals (and even surpasses) Steven Hawking in some areas. There is a fair amount of math, but he allows the non-math reader to take that part on faith. One major strength is his ability to translate four-dimensional concepts into some of the best three-dimensional analogies I've seen.

Does a pretty good job of explaining some arcane and non-intuitive concepts, and illustrates the inevitability of each concept leading to the next. Goes off the rails a bit in the chapter on spacetime, which is a tangled mash of equations and not very good analogies requiring some re-reading and brow-furrowing, but overall is an excellent fairly-popular explanation of the subject

This books makes me feel like I might actually be smart enough to understand it. It's gentle, inviting, humorous at times, and down right charming. I still can't fully wrap my head around warping spacetime, but that's probably my problem. I think I'll read this book again sometime, and try again. Everything else was presented so clearly and simply that I really think I got it! Yeah me!

One of the most intuitive explanations of Einstein's theories I've ever had the pleasure of coming across. It's a shame that the end seemed to wind up relatively abruptly, skimming over much of the details of general relativity. But still a great digestible packaging of complex ideas and thoroughly exciting for someone with an interest in physics.
Very Mathematical and Scientific and a lot of interesting facts! Small diagrams to show a good example and I love it
