Wonderful. Well written, accessible, funny. The best praise I can give it is that it took away a fear of calculus I've had since I mostly blew off the subject Freshman year of college. I found myself working out an equation in the book.

I enjoyed this book. I am an operator at a nuclear power plant, and love science.It isn't always easy to wrap your head around some of the concepts, and I had to re-read some paragraphs, but it is an excellent resource for finding out about physics.

Came upon this book while browsing in The Commons Borders with Christopher on Saturday, 21 August 2010.Review of this book in the 20 October 2010 issue of The Independent, London, in an article entitled "Endangered: The Science Book Prize."

I remember why I didn't enjoy physics at school, this was a tough read. Although the authors did a lot to simplify the concepts, which in themselves I could understand the maths just made this book a difficult read.

Some of this book is interesting, but a lot of it is kind of tedious. Like the huge chapter on deriving E=mc^2, it didn't do much for me, but the rest of the book was pretty interesting. If you're into that short of thing.

Hard to read in multiple short sittings. easy to forget what was said in previous chapter. You also need to do the math no matter what they say, otherwise you are just taking their word for it. Would rather watch this being explained but thats probably just me.

Good overview of relativity with some great examples and thought provoking ideas. Read it at the same time as my brother in Australia (I live in the UK) which was a blast. We had some great discussions on the nature of time arising from the book.

Challenging at parts (will I ever really truly "get" the concept of space-time?) but very rewarding. I felt it was a good balance of covering concepts and ideas, while digging into just enough math and science to challenge but not frighten a lay person.

It was an interesting book with some excellent history. It could have been half the size if it didn't keep repeating the same things over and over again. I would have liked more maths to illustrate the text. It did make me get out a book on Maxwell and his equations.

I learned about neutrinos from reading this book, and I have never been the same. I absolutely loved it reading it. I'm a math failure, but this book made concepts that I'd love to understand, easy to understand. 7 zillion thumbs up.

some of this is great but some of the metaphors are so dull I use the book to induce sleep. They manage to be cool about using 'she' for 'generic person / scientist' but then slip into boyspeak... not bad so far

Nice read for the science simpleton. The author writes for the reader with no technical background so he has to oversimplify a bit but still very well written. Cox's writing inspires a person to take complex ideas and explain them simply for everyone to appreciate.

A fun read for a Physicist. While aimed at the general public, I wonder if the book will quite resonate with the intended audience. On the other hand, I plan to recommend the book to my first year Physics class.

Cox spoils an otherwise promising book with moments of condescending language and an immature writing style. To Cox's credit, the content was straight-forward and interesting. I did learn something about why E=Mc2 from this book, but overall, this book is not what it promised to be.

Great refresher on a good deal of material I'd already covered, but unique nonetheless because of authors' insistence on stepping us through equations for the key concepts. Worthwhile trip even without the math.

A very nice book about Astronomy, Physics, Science and Scientists, that should appeal to a wide range of people as it very approachable and interesting, and sheds some light on the most well know equation in the world, how it came to be and why it's so damn important.

Quite simply the best "popular" exposition of Quantum Mechanics that I have come across. I write as a chemistry graduate from 1972 so we did some quantum mechanics then, but it's taken then intervening 40 years to become appreciative of the subject!

I did O Level Physics a very long time ago! I haven't given up wanting to understand how it all works, and Brian Cox gives me confidence that one day I might actually get it. This book's doing a good job so far. I think.

This popular science book is written on the pattern of a riveting novel starting from our intuitive perception of time and space... from there a world of personal and scientific exploration opens that leads us to a deep understanding of E=mc2. Never pedantic, always fluid.

This book is so easy to understand and explains so much! It's also quite funny which makes it easier to read and I felt like I'd achieved something when I finished it. I was like 'I know, I'll go and get a degree in Physics! I must be well on my way already!' Then I didn't.

Didn't finish it. It was all going along quite nicely till near the end of the 'Spacetime' chapter, and then I lost the thread completely. I might try again, because the book is really very well written - clear and straightforward without being patronising.

The first half of the book was really good. Well written, easy to understand and put in a really interesting way. And then the second half suddenly became inaccessible, seemingly written by a completely different person!

This was quite an interesting book. I will admit that my brain felt a bit frazzled after some of the maths sections but I am glad I stuck with them. The book is well explained and the author communicates their enthusiasm for thhe subject very clearly.

Beyond the stuff you'd expect of Brian Cox (an abundance of superlatives, long rambling passages telling you how beautiful and straightforward everything is) this is a pretty coherent, engaging account. And there's no irrelevant scenery for him to stand in front of looking windswept.

Enter with a modest understanding, or at the very least, an appreciation of physics. Far more accessible than the average text book and much wittier. I'm on a science book reading kick currently and this title didn't disappoint.

Very concise explanations but I think the book should of been special relativity specific as opposed to incorporating the standard model of fundamental particles. This book helped me massively during my project for college and was the most reliable source I found.

One of the most difficult times I've had with reading a book on Physics. I really like Brian Cox but something in this made it much more complicated than it needed to be and that's not something I expect from him.

Two stars isn't really a reflection on the book itself more on the woeful state of my own mathematics and physics.The "Professors" have done their best to make the book accessible to non-scientists but it was a step too far for me!

The authors alternated between giving too much details especially with the math and not enough jumping to conclusion without explaining. I enjoyed the last few chapters When they wrote just about concepts abandoning the math

The authors have done a great job at explaining some of EInstein's work in a simple way...I listened to the audiobook and although I had to sometime rewind to really get some of the concepts explained I found the overall book very accessible and very satisfying.

Very easy to understand, but very difficult to remember. There is a lot of maths in this book, so it's only really enjoyable if you're properly invested in finding out the answer to the titular question (it's not forty-two).

A mind blowing change of perspective on how you see the universe is hidden somewhere in each chapter. This book is a fantastic description of the theories of special and general relativity for people who are unfamiliar or intimidated by the mathematics involved.

It's a good read but i'm afraid my little grey cells aren't to taking it in at first bite, no fault to the authors, it lies squarely with this reader. However once I've read something a bit easier like "War and peace" I'll take another run at it. =)

I probably didn't understand the authors' explanations. Their arguments were not convincing. Again, "Why does E=mc**2? and why do we care?". The book is short, but not short enough. I couldn't wait for it to end. It was just too boring.

Amazing book... by far the best physics book I have read to date. Unfortunately, two-thirds the way through it was way over my head. I will have to re-read it again and again and again. I cannot wait!

By virtue of the reputation of Professor Brian Cox and his gently charisma shown on BBC, I picked up this book for deepening my understanding about physics, especially the general relativity by the forever genius in human history - Albert Einstein.

I kinda sorta understand special relativity now! General, not so much. But this book does an excellent job at explaining the geometry of Minkowski space which is extremely difficult to comprehend and must be even harder to explain. This book is also a great particle physics primer.

I really enjoyed this book. It was written in a very easy to read manner so that no matter how little physics you know you will be able to understand the concepts. I left this book with a much more clear understanding of the physics described.

And I thought, at first- yes, an accessible astrophysical literature, finally, I will understand it- but as it continued, the maths started to meddle with my eyes. Maybe I am too young, not clever enough, never studied physics... Still, at times, interesting, I got to know few things
